title: BHP says Scope 3 push will protect demand for products
text:
''By making sure our own house is in order, and by protecting demand for our products we will preserve and create value for BHP."

Mr Healy said BHP's WA iron ore division was conducting polling of communities in the Pilbara region to discover "what was material to them and how we are managing those issues''.

That polling was then fed into the "thousands" of decisions that site managers made each year which had an impact on communities, including decisions over where to source labour and suppliers.

Mr Healy said BHP was less likely to be the target of aggressive government policies like mining taxes if community sentiment toward the company was positive, and that had prompted the company to run its "Think big'' television commercials in recent years.

''Our research also confirmed that when communities feel connected to us, and see us as contributing fairly, the pressure for populist rent-seeking policies significantly reduces,'' he said.

''Since 2017, we have undertaken targeted campaigns at both national and regional levels; and we’re seeing a measurable difference in public perception.

''We know this broad based support in cities and regions is essential to creating value and returns for all stakeholders, and in particular for shareholders.''

The comments echo Mr Mackenzie's pitch to investors in May, where he urged the mining industry to abandon the traditional notion of "social licence to operate".

''Our industry, we feel needs to make a proactive shift, beyond the mindset of licence, which is about seeking permission, to one of partnership, the genuine and sustainable creation of value and benefits for the whole of society and this work has to be bedrocked for everything we do, it has to be the foundation from which we can grow our business,'' he told investors at the BAML conference in Barcelona.

''That is why things like carbon capture and storage, and indigenous peoples advocacy, are actions that we hold and set us up for sustained shareholder returns".

BHP shares closed 23¢ higher at $35.61.
description: Towns in Western Australia's iron ore heartland will be polled monthly by BHP in a bid to ensure the miner makes decisions that are appreciated by locals
